title: Modeling Company Risk and Importance in Supply Graphs
segmentation: Good afternoon everyone.

So as was mentioned in the introduction, I want to kick off this session by talking a little bit about our work that we did on modeling company risk as well as importance in supply graphs or a supply graph.
And to sort of explain why.

We mean by that I wanted to start off with an example, and broadly, there's obviously many, many good reasons why a company or someone else might be interested in checking, evaluating, managing their supply chain and what happens in a supply chain.
But I just picked out one example, so recently there was in investigative report by Amnesty International who were looking into the doings and happenings of the palm oil industry.

And it turns out that a lot of big corporates that claimed to be using sustainable palm oil actually weren't really doing that because they were implicated and we're getting supplied by a company called Wilma who it turns out was actually using child labor as well as forced labor so.

Obviously it's probably fair to assume that some of these companies may have been aware of who Wilma is, maybe even that there was something fishy going on, but at the same time, oftentimes what can happen is that these connections between companies are in direct supply relations, so with supply relations we talk about when we talk about tiers.
So a first tier supplier is a supplier that directly provides a company with goods, a second tier supplier is a supplier of a supplier, so on and so forth.
So it might have been the case for some of these companies that they were linked to Wilmer, but not directly that they had a supplier who was in turn getting the palm oil from Wilma.
And of course nevertheless they ended up in this report and we're getting incredibly bad press.

So with these types of situations and many other situations we were looking at what's happening with supply chains, how they analyzed and we were wondering whether we could do something to help essentially.
Improve this visibility down a supply chain where company might know.
OK, we have these suppliers but they might not know what's happening beyond that.
So who are the suppliers of my suppliers and so on?
So what we've done to?

Dude, that is so we have a knowledge graph within Thomson Reuters and from that knowledge graph we extracted a subset which we for this purpose can call a supply graph which is based basically on RDF triplestore where each triple is made up of two companies, a supplier and a customer, and the relation which is a supply relation.
So there's only one type of predicate.
And in the resulting graph, then obviously nodes represent companies and these companies are linked through directed relations pointing from a supplier to a customer.
So with this graph, what we then wanted to do to sort of help gaining insight about these situations where maybe you know who your suppliers are, but what's happening beyond that is very unclear.
We wanted to utilize this graph representation to identify certain risks that companies who might be your suppliers are exposed to.

And Secondly, we also wanted to try and come up with a way of assigning a certain importance to these suppliers, and so I'll basically spend the rest of the talk just briefly walking you through how we measure these two aspects of what a supplier might look like and how we could evaluate a supplier, whether that's direct or indirect suppliers.
And then I'll briefly talk about how we built it and how we represented the output of this analysis.
So.
The first score, then is trying to measure the importance of a supplier to a customer.

Again, what we wanted to do was to gain visibility beyond the so called first tier, so that's why I wanted the graph representation and then within that graph representation we wanted to build a representation of importance of suppliers to customers and we aggregate.
We aggregate importance from a number of scores, so I've named them here and I'll briefly explain them in the next slide, which is a combination of.
Graph based scores as well as attributes of the companies that make up this graph.
So the before I move on to the actual scores, just a brief note on the data that we used.

So essentially two datasets that we picked up and pull together for this one I've already mentioned was the Triple Store and this was this is the triples were mined from the web, so we basically had a bunch of candidates candidate patterns that based on which we extracted phrases and then we had a supervised classifier.
Classify them either as containing a supply relation or not containing a supply relation.
The second data set that we used is from a product we have called that is called perm ID and I have I have the link at the end as well so you can try it out if you like.
It's basically large database that contains lots of entities, primarily organizations that such as companies.

That are assigned a set of attributes for companies that might be, for example, where the company is based on the legal entity type or the industry that a company operates in this then and I'll show how that fits in later is basically turned into a slider and I'll explain later why it is a slider, but.
Just a few words on the actual measures that we used, so we came up with four measures, essentially that we then aggregate into a single measure.
The 1st two are essentially graph based measures where the 3rd and 4th measure are based on attributes of the companies.
So the first one criticality we use the datasets called the world Input Output database, which basically is a summary of.
Data that is used to evaluate how much certain industries supply to each other.
So the notion here is that if a company, if its supply operates in an industry that.
On average supplies, a lot of goods to the industry the customer operates in.
Then we assign a higher criticality, the second one, replaceability is again around which industries the suppliers operate in.
And here we make sort of a simplifying assumption by saying that.
Companies in similar industries provides similar goods.

So in the second example up there, so if we were to say that CO2 three and four marketing green operate in the same industry and supply to company five, we would consider them to be more replaceable than, for example company one because Co one is the only supplier from that industry to Company 5.
The 3rd and 4th measure then are simple graph based measures where centrality.
Gives us a notion of how how structurally important suppliers or or any company to the overall graph.
There's different measures of centrality.
One is, for example, how many shortest paths within a graph passed through a particular node and distance is just straightforward.
How far away a supplier is from a customer.
So customer two to customer three is the step distance one customer 123 step distance two and so on and so forth.
So this is how we measure important.
And as I said, we aggregate these and we wait.
We wait them currently equally and I'll get to that point a bit later again.
So the second measure that we then wanted to integrate.
As I mentioned earlier, is.
Risk and again same as with importance.
There might be whole variety of options of how we measure risk.

What we chose was to essentially take one of the many industry standards around credit risk rating and basically the rating the risk rating that we chose measures or gives the gives it provides a likelihood of how likely a company is to default on one or more of their debts within the next 12 months.

And the idea behind that was that we wanted to show yes, a company might be important to your supplier, might be important to you, but that might be moderated by other factors such as risk in this case.
So, for example, say we have a very important supplier, but we know everything smooth sailing everything is humming along nicely on their end.
Maybe we don't care too much, or we don't need to put in place any mitigation risk mitigation strategies, whereas with a supplier that might be somewhat less vital to our supply chain, but.
We know is about to go bankrupt.
Maybe we need to pay closer attention to how we want to address that, so that's the rescore and then together with the important score we.

Put that into an architecture that is based on a graph database, so we pull out the RDF data from our Knowledge graph and we store all the data that I mentioned, so the supply relations, the company data which comes from the Perm ID application that I mentioned, as well as the credit risk.
Or should we take all that and pull it into a Neo 4 J database, which is a graph database and this has a query language, a dedicated query language called Cipher.
Just basically a version or a way of similar to SQL, just tailored to graph databases.
We each of these two scores it can or the database is queried via two APIs, one for important scoring and the other one for the rescoring.
So basically what the API does is it receives a company as a request which is the customer and what we then want to do.
Using the data is we want to extract the set of suppliers that could be 123 or however many steps into the graph that we're interested in.
We want to then score these suppliers according to how important they are to the particular company and what risk.
What risk or they have, and then the API returns these two scores.
These two sets of scores with the list of companies in the form of Jason Files and.
The the reason for that is that we have an application which is sad.
In internal application, otherwise I would've demo'd it.
But basically what this is doing is it's a very simple interface that just provides a search capability and it visualizes the output in a ranking.
So basically what's happening here you can see at the top that the user can search for a company and that then sends a request to the API's that I've just mentioned that I've built that we've built.
And then return.
Jason is just simply visualized in this way so.

At the moment you can just see as a simple ranking where the higher score is on top both the measure step of described weighted equally and that's where the aforementioned sliders come in because basically the user can then go in and say.
Well, maybe I don't, maybe I don't care so much about the risk so they can change the weighting and say look, I maybe keep the risk.
Don't throw it out completely, but let's focus on which companies are important.
So this is one way that we try to visualize the output that we got from from the data.
Another thing that we tried.
Was to break it out further, so I mentioned earlier that we had these four different.
Proxies for importance we could, you could say and instead of aggregating it here, we just kept it broken up into the four individual components still plus the risk rating.
So this then just gives us a different view and essentially hands the user a bit more power in deciding what they care about, because now they have five different options to play around with and.

Having done all this, so we had sort of the conceptual idea, what can we do to help with analyzing supply chains beyond the first year, beyond what companies might already know the question was then not so much for the risk, but for the importance the question was.
Are we actually using reasonable proxies to represent importance?

The question wasn't so much, therefore the risk, because it's basically an industry standard measure of risk, so it's been used over and over by companies around the world, whereas with the importance we basically basically started from scratch, so we didn't go very far into trying to figure out whether the risk scores were useful, but we try to think about how we could evaluate whether our way of measuring and aggregating importance.
Actually reflects what's happening in the real world, So what we did as a first first approach.
Which was to take 200 text snippets and so remember that the triples that we used for the supply relations are extracted from text.
So we take the original text snippets and take the containing the triple that is contained and extracted from that snippet and score it using the described methodology.
And from that we take the 20 that are that were scored the highest.

In the 20 that we scored the lowest and we randomly match one of each two with each other and then we gave that to human judges to say which one of these pairs, or which one of these snippets do you think signifies a more important relation between the two companies mentioned in that snippet?
And we then compared whether the human judgment actually reflected.
The scoring that we got so was.
Was a snippet that or triple that was scored more highly using our methodology?
Did the human judges say the same thing?
Did they also say that's more important?
Turns out the agreement was fairly low, so our first idea for the experiment was I think it's fair to say rather inconclusive.
So with this we we are at the moment, not really sure whether we have chosen good proxies.
These four notions of importance that we pull together.
The I would say the verdict is still out and that really brings me as well too.
The outcome and the big open questions you could say.

So what we what we've done is that we believe we really developed the first interactive and automatically scored way of evaluating relations in the supply chain that are go beyond the direct suppliers as well as.
Integrating different notions of what, what, what's relevant, and I'm just mentioning relevant, so I hope that's good.
So here we have importance and risk.

And also it's easily what we've done is easily extensible, because the way we've implemented it together with the interface that I've shown you screenshots of, it's just a matter of adding APIs and removing APIs, so it's very flexible and the APIs are very simple.
So of course, as you can see from especially the evaluation, there's quite a few open questions.
So as I mentioned, we've made a couple of simplifying assumptions because the data doesn't tell us what exactly is supplied by the suppliers.
We just have attributes of suppliers and customers.

We had to sort of abstract away from the concrete exchange of goods and say, OK, what do we know we know about which industries these companies operate in, But the question is, is that a fair assumption?
That sort of.
Tells us something about the importance.
Then based on that, the second question is did we actually choose good proxies for importance or are there better measures then industry and graph structure for example?
And as I mentioned this while we waited the scores equally, so we had these four different scores.
And when we aggregated them, we assign them each equal importance essentially.
Question is whether that's fair or whether we should.
For example, as I mentioned in the next slide, should we try and find a way of learning these weights and then Lastly?

Of course, as I mentioned in the previous slide, the evaluation was to say it likely inconclusive, so we believe that there was anecdotal evidence that our important scoring was useful and I'll get back to the original example to explain that in a second.
But of course, because of the low agreement in our initial experiment, we think there's open questions there and we need to go further into that.
So just a quick note on the anecdotal evidence.
So we actually.
So we took this report from Amnesty International that I mentioned earlier and we.

Searched for the companies that were mentioned in the report and it turns out so we searched for six of the corporates and we were trying to see whether Wilma was a supplier of those companies for five of the six we found that they were listed and they were ranked as highly as the 11th most important supplier of I think.
In that case it was Kellogg so we did find for this particular example and we checked a few other examples and.

It's it seemed that there was some evidence that for the examples that we looked at, we could find confirming examples, but obviously that doesn't amount to an evaluation, so there needs to be much more work we put into that.
So then just to wrap up the.
The thing that really builds on the open questions is what we believe the next steps should be.
So the first point is sort of obvious.
I guess it's always nice to have more data and higher quality data.
We in that respect.
For this point we are lucky because the Knowledge graph that we've extracted the data from is being actively maintained.
So if we if we went back today to redo the same experiments we would we would work with a larger data set and same in a months time.
Same in two months time.
Then for the next step is would it be worth learning the weights of the proxies for importance to try and combine them in a different way in a more informed way than just waiting them equally?
And also it might be worth both for risk and for importance to look at other measures so there's other risk measures of course.
For example, we could look at country risks so there's measures for how risky it is to do business in a country.
So could that be interesting if we know suppliers based in a high risk country, will that be worth integrating?
And would that tell us something else and then finally again coming back to the valuation?

We need a different evaluation methodology that might still be based on human evaluation, but maybe for example we need subject matter expert experts who can actually tell us these two companies are closely linked, so they should be up there.
Or these two aren't, so you're wrong so with.
Note I would like to thank you and I'm on 20 minutes.
I just want to point you to a few websites.
The top one is so we were making available.
Anonymized version of the data that we used for these experiments.
Obviously because it's our proprietary data.
We couldn't just release the data set, but we figured it be nice to give some give you something which is basically it's the same data set just with the company.
Remove company names removed to the structure of the graph is exactly the same as what we've used.
So if you look in the paper like the graph, measures will be the same and then the other two.
The bottom two are just applications.
So I mentioned perm ID.
An open Calais is.
Tagging engine, so that's that forms the basis for example.
So it's got named entity recognition, so that's formed.
The basis of the data that was extracted from the news detects that made up the makes up the Knowledge Graph.
So yeah, with that I'll finish up.
I'll be happy to take any questions.
